articles.headline: Government Offers Details of Bank Stress Test
articles.snippet: Banks that fail the test would have to provide securities that could be converted to common stock in order to get additional government funds.
articles.abstract: Banks that fail the test would have to provide securities that could be converted to common stock in order to get additional government funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration ordered the nation’s 19 biggest banks on Wednesday to undergo stress tests to check whether they could hold up if the economy deteriorated further.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Preparing for a Flood of Energy Efficiency Spending
articles.snippet: Experts worry that cities aren’t ready to oversee the energy-efficiency money coming their way.
articles.abstract: Experts worry that cities aren’t ready to oversee the energy-efficiency money coming their way.
articles.lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — To the casual eye, the basement of this city’s Firehouse 9 looks like a jumble of old hydrants, Dr Pepper cartons, rakes and random gear. To specialists in energy efficiency, the 1960s-era building is a mess of a different sort: wasteful hot water heaters for the firefighters’ showers, ancient refrigerators and outdated lights.

articles.headline: Rules for the New Reality
articles.snippet: In the economic downturn, financial advisers have been taken to task. But what, exactly, does your wealth manager owe you? And what can you never reasonably expect?
articles.abstract: In the economic downturn, financial advisers have been taken to task. But what, exactly, does your wealth manager owe you? And what can you never reasonably expect?
articles.lead_paragraph: BACK in September, before we were all inured to the tottering nature of so many financial giants, investors were looking for someone to blame.

articles.headline: Geniuses at Play, on the Job
articles.snippet: Let’s sift through some of the lesser-known projects created during Google’s “20 percent time.”
articles.abstract: Let’s sift through some of the lesser-known projects created during Google’s “20 percent time.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Unless you’re just off the shuttle from Alpha Centauri, you’re already aware of the product that made Google famous: its Search box. It’s become the card catalog for the Internet (and a whopping moneymaker for Google).

articles.headline: Falling Revenues Threaten Rebuilding in Iraq
articles.snippet: The financial crisis and falling oil prices will make it harder for Iraq to pay for services and could affect U.S. plans for withdrawal.
articles.abstract: The financial crisis and falling oil prices will make it harder for Iraq to pay for services and could affect U.S. plans for withdrawal.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  In few nations around the globe are the consequences of the financial crisis as potentially sobering as they are in Iraq. Both oil revenues and American financial support have plummeted just as the country has the chance to take advantage of its increasing stability to improve basic services and upgrade its ruined infrastructure.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and James Glanz

articles.headline: Son’s Death Recasts Image of a British Leader
articles.snippet: The life and death of David Cameron’s young disabled son have helped bridge a social gap between him and Britain.
articles.abstract: The life and death of David Cameron’s young disabled son have helped bridge a social gap between him and Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Ivan Cameron was just 6, a boy with a lovely smile who was born with cerebral palsy and a severe form of epilepsy that deprived him of the ability to walk, talk or feed himself. He spent much of his time in the hospital, sometimes with his parents sleeping on the floor beside him, helping care for their “beautiful boy.”

articles.headline: Drug Maker Is Accused of Fraud
articles.snippet: The Justice Department charged Forest Laboratories with defrauding the government of millions of dollars by illegally marketing the antidepressants Celexa and Lexapro.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department charged Forest Laboratories with defrauding the government of millions of dollars by illegally marketing the antidepressants Celexa and Lexapro.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department charged the drug maker Forest Laboratories on Wednesday with defrauding the government of millions of dollars by illegally marketing the popular antidepressants Celexa and Lexapro for unapproved uses in children and teenagers.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Benedict Carey

articles.headline: U.S. Is Arms Bazaar for Mexican Cartels
articles.snippet: A case against a Phoenix gun store owner offers a glimpse of how weapons delivered to U.S. gun dealers are moved into Mexico and wielded in horrific crimes.
articles.abstract: A case against a Phoenix gun store owner offers a glimpse of how weapons delivered to U.S. gun dealers are moved into Mexico and wielded in horrific crimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  The Mexican agents who moved in on a safe house full of drug dealers last May were not prepared for the fire power that greeted them.

articles.headline: Big U.S. Role in Lending to Students
articles.snippet: The government has increased its support of the student loan market so much that there is a question of whether there is a role for private lenders at all.
articles.abstract: The government has increased its support of the student loan market so much that there is a question of whether there is a role for private lenders at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government has quietly increased its support of the student loan market to such a degree that the real question may be whether there is a role left for private lenders at all.

articles.headline: To Pay for Health Care, Obama Looks to Taxes on Affluent
articles.snippet: President Obama’s budget will call for stricter limits on itemized deductions, introducing a politically volatile edge to the debate over his domestic priorities.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s budget will call for stricter limits on itemized deductions, introducing a politically volatile edge to the debate over his domestic priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama will propose further tax increases on the affluent to help pay for his promise to make health care more accessible and affordable, calling for stricter limits on the benefits of itemized deductions taken by the wealthiest households, administration officials said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear

articles.headline: G.M. Lays Its Future on Washington’s Doorstep
articles.snippet: Rick Wagoner, the chief executive of General Motors, met with government officials to discuss the carmaker’s finances after the company reported a $9.6 billion loss for the quarter.
articles.abstract: Rick Wagoner, the chief executive of General Motors, met with government officials to discuss the carmaker’s finances after the company reported a $9.6 billion loss for the quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — If there were any remaining questions in Washington about the depths of financial problems at General Motors, they were answered Thursday by the automaker’s dismal 2008 results.

articles.headline: Obama Plans Major Shifts in Spending
articles.snippet: President Obama’s budget plan tries to trim a deficit estimated at $1.75 trillion for 2009 as it redirects wide streams of spending.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s budget plan tries to trim a deficit estimated at $1.75 trillion for 2009 as it redirects wide streams of spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Proclaiming a “once in a generation” opportunity, President Obama proposed a 10-year budget on Thursday that reflects his determination in the face of recession to invest trillions of dollars and his own political capital in reshaping the nation’s priorities.
